bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to [his parents], June 9, 1941

div1.p: Hench writes to [his parents] about his recent trip east; where he attended medical conventions, spoke at the unveiling of Dean Cornwell's “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” painting, and enjoyed alumni events at his alma mater.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to [his parents], June 9, 1941
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
Monday aft 6/9/41
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
Dear Frek,
div1.p:
Well I arrived home this morning from my second eastern
jaunt within a week. Let me tell you a little about them.
It was not originally planned to show Cornwell's paintings
“Conquerors of yellow Fever” at the A.M.A. as it wasn't
finished. He says he has two more month's work to do on it
altho it looks practically finished to a layman's eye. But about
2 weeks before AMA they decided to use it (The Wyeth Co) as the
center of their AMA exhibit. So they arranged a private pre-view
& dedication of it. My wired & asked me to give the main address.
& paid my expenses there & back. It was my year to stay home from
the AMA & Chuck Slocumb's year to go so at first I didn't see
how I could go. The clinic thought I could get away for 1 1/2
days alright so I went. It was most fortunate for me because
this I was able to attend the executive committee meeting
of our American Rheumatism Association and also
most of the scientific sessions of the ARA on the same Monday
as the unveiling of the painting

I had a long cold with fever & was in bed Thursday &
Friday before going to Cleveland. Indeed on Thursday
night my voice was gone & with my fever Dr Mueler said
I couldn't go to Cleveland at all. But I inhaled
steam vigorously & felt well enough to go on Sat. aft.
with Chuck Slucomb. We got to our hotel Sunday morning
& I got in touch with Mr. Kellogg who arranged this
unveiling. We went over the plans & then I had
dinner & a rest alone in my hotel bedroom.
In the afternoon from 3 till 7 PM we had our
executive meeting & I gave the report of our military
committee. Eighteen of us are offering our services to the Surgeon
General as specialists to be used if necessary. These 18 were very
carefully chosen. I am one of them. Of course we may never be called
but Col Hillman of the Surgeon General's office was most anxious
to have us ready &willing.

At 7 Mr Chuck & I & others were invited to Dr. Stecher's for
buffet supper. He is one of my friends & a member of our council. He
seems to be quite wealthy & has a beautiful home - an estate really-
right on the lake. We enjoyed a grand dinner & stayed till 11 P.M.
Monday morning we had a most excellent session of our Rheumatism
association - it was just splendid. Highly scientific & most
promising. How far our association has gone since we founded it
a few years ago. As a founder I felt very proud. I had been
allowed to invite from 5-10 guests of my own to the unveiling
but it was so late that I only invited about 6 & only 3 of them
could come. Dr Frank Edmundsen (Sue's husband) & Dr &
Mrs Walter Simpson of Dayton Ohio. We all met at 12 o'clock
It was a small but very elite affair- About 45 guests
including the Mayor of Cleveland, the President of the AMA
(who sat next to me), the President elect of the AMA, Surgeon-
General Ireland & wife, Mr Kissinger, Walter Reed's daughter,
We all sat at the head table with Dr Mulholland (Atch's
friend from Charlottesville representing the U of Va). The guests
included some physicians & directors of art institutions etc.
Unfortunately the Pres. & Pres-elect of the AMA were trying to
spread themselves very thin & sneak around to as many
luncheons etc as possible so they only stayed for the first 2
courses as they had promised to drop in on another lunch
somewhere. So we had to stop while the meal was in
progress & have the unveiling before my talk rather than
last as planned. Mrs Reed who sat next to me
pulled the ribbons & unveiled it & the photographers snapped
her with the AMA Presidents & then they (the men) left.
We continued our meal & then the mayor (a very nice man
by the way) gave a nice little speech of welcome & then
Mr. Law the President of the Wyeth Co. introduced me
most flatteringly. I then gave “the address” & it was
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
very obvious that it was very well received. I was most pleased &
later heard many nice things said of it. Dr Carey, Dean of
Marquette University Med. School invited me right then & there
to come to Marquette to give it next fall. I understand (confidently)
that it is to be printed & a copy sent with each copy of the
painting to over 100, 000 medical men. After I finished
Kissinger spoke very briefly - 2 or 3 nice modest sentences.
Then Gen. Ireland spoke only a minute or so & that ended the
affair. Photographs were then taken of those of us in the ceremony
(see enclosed) & then Mr. Cornwell (I forgot to say he gave a 10
minute most interesting artistic analysis & of his
painting. Why this & that were done etc) asked Mr. Kissinger
to pose for some sketches so that he could change Kissinger's
features in the painting somewhat. That was Monday at 3 PM.
While we were chatting Mr Kissinger told me he hadn't felt
any too well and had recently had an “affair” which
affected his face. As he told me this I wondered to myself
if he could have had stroke which cleared up. Well
while I was in Easton I got a wire that Mr. K had arrived
home Wed, felt well & happy, told Mrs. K all about the
affair & then suddenly had a severe stroke. Mrs K told me
he was unconscious & not expected to live! Isn't that
sad. I have wired & today I wrote her a letter, I've
heard no more & don't know whether he is recovering,
living or dead. Incidentally he asked about my “lovely
mother.” He is a nice old fellow, a gallant soldier & a
simple Christian gentleman & I hope he can recover but if he's
to be paralyzed I hope he goes now.

I got back to our Rheumatism meeting about 3 P M, it lasted till 5
& at 730 we had a very nice banquet. One of our men had been
in England 6 months in an operating unit & gave us a fine
talk on conditions in England. I left at midnight,
got to Winna Tuesday noon whereMary met me.

I left forEaston Thursday on the 400, got to the Easton
hotel Friday about 7 PM. They had reserved for me the same
room we had last year. It was nice to have it but it made
me feel lonesome not to have Mary with me, you & the kids
in the next room & Atch nearby, I ran into some alumni
almost at once - Chuck Siebert, Judge whats-his-name etc
& they spoke of facts so nicely etc. Then I went up on the hill to
hear the step singing in front of Pander. Met several friends
including Dr Berg (spelling?) the man who cabed me for my
honorary degree in the ceremony last year. He was kind enough
to say that they were very pleased & proud to have given me the
degree. I met Dr Hall, Dr Gordon, Foster & a couple other
old teachers - all asked of you & Atch. & Dr Gordon
told an amusing story about father (too long to enclose).

At 9 I went to our 116 headquarters, the plumbing
establishment of my Easton classmate Stipe. They had
all the beer & pretzel and ginger ale any one could drink
& we just sat around & laughed & sang etc till 2 AM!
There were almost 60 who dropped in & out during the
evening. Some I hadn't seen for 25 years! among them
Bing Gayvar in whose home I stayed during the days
I was “expelled” from the college - Atch will recall him-
It was a swell evening. Some of us got together
& we had some marvellous harmony on all the old
songs. Atch may remember Tom Brown (baseball player)
who lived in Dowell near us. Boy did we sing! My voice was gone by 2 AM!

The town parade started at 1030 & we had about 50
in line. The weather was bright - a bit hot.

The parade ended at the foot of the hill - a very good crowd of
town folk watched it - more than I remember on the streets & also
in line. In the parade I ran into Tom Williams, my classmate
& fraternity brother whom I haven't seen for 25 years! After we all
had our class photo taken at the foot of the hill Tom & I
went up & wandered over the campus It was beautiful!
We met an old prof - I can't recall his name - he said “
all the Henches were smart - a fine family - fine students
all!”. I was much pleased but wondered if he met
George Hench & Tom! I was taking a few colored movies
near Pavell Hall when a woman came up & said “Do you
chance have an extra film in your camera?” I said I did
the same “I realize I'm presumptious but my father & 3 of his old
classmates are here together. They made us arrangements to have
a photo taken & it may be their last get together. Could you
take a little snapshot? ” I said “surely”. Then I asked the
four nice old men what class they belonged to. They said
188! So I told them my father was Hench '83 They just
beamed. They all knew him & one man said “Why you're
Philip Hench. I've known of you since you were a baby & I
knew your parents very very well.” It was Mr. A. P.
Bachman who is a lawyer in New York now (150 Nassau
St. New York City). The others were J Frank Briggs
Middletown, Delaware, WO Sample of Easton & Edwards
M Haymaker who works & generally lives in Guatamala
but whose home was in Warrensburg, Mo. Do you recall
any of them aside from Mr. Bachman? Well we had a
fine chat & their ladies seemed so happy that I could
take the photos. I hope they turn out alright.

at the alumni lunch I sat with my class.
They had an exhibit a large painting of old Frankie's
March in his office surrounded by piles & piles of
books & magazines. It was a swell painting made from an old
photo. After the luncheon a photo was taken of all of the
alumni who had had old Frankie as a teacher, with the
painting behind them. They are planning to raise money for
a Frankie Hall Memorial Bldg of some sort.

Then we paraded around the campus & baseball field.
I still got a thrill when we mass hands & march down to
onward Christian Soldiers. Lafayette won the game - a good
& exciting game but it was so hot & my hay fever bothered
me so I left at 5 for the hotel & a bath. At 630 we
had a class banquet after which Archie Wood &
Creveling & I showed various movies of old reunions
we'd taken. They wanted to see the one of me receiving
my degree and many of my classmates were generous
enough to congratulate me on it.

The banquet was over at 9 & I left at 9 58 via
Buffalo, the Welland Canal, the Canadian shore of Lake
Erie, Duluth & Chicago. Got there last night & home
this morning after a swell trip. But I was a bit
lonesome remembering that last year I had all my family
with me.

I enclose various clippings, photos etc. Please return
them soon. Now at last I expect to be here awhile
I certainly have counted east these last weeks &
been away more than I've been here. And heavy season
is on & we have hundreds of patients!
div1.closer:
Love to all. Philip Bill Comrod wasn't
there. a number of profs asked for
you (mother) & Atch. Many of my classmates also
asked about Atch most kindly & applauded
him when he appeared in my movie.
